cards.title: TV review / The Affair, The World's Most Expensive Food and Shark
cards.rawTitle: The Affair, The World's Most Expensive Food and Shark

item.title: The Affair, The World's Most Expensive Food and Shark: TV review
item.trailText: Telly addict Andrew Collins reviews this week's TV, including the Long Island-set infidelity drama The Affair on Sky Atlantic
item.standFirst:
Telly addict Andrew Collins reviews this week's TV, wondering who to believe in the Long Island-set infidelity drama The Affair on Sky Atlantic; dismissing Twin-Peaks-meets-The-Truman-Show hybrid Wayward Pines on Fox; feeling physically sick at the antics of the super-rich on C4's The World's Most Expensive Food; marvelling at Shark on BBC1; welcoming the return of sitcom-within-a-sitcom Episodes to BBC2; and finding Zen in HBO's Last Week Tonight

• WARNING: STRONG LANGUAGE

cards.title: Australia / Where the rain is sometimes made of spiders
cards.rawTitle: Where the rain is sometimes made of spiders

item.title: Australia: where spiders rain down from the sky - video report
item.trailText: The Australian town of Goulburn was recently covered by spiders raining from the sky, but how did it happen and why?
item.standFirst: The Australian town of Goulburn, NSW, was recently covered by spiders raining from the sky, but how did it happen and why? Whilst this would probably cause mass panic in the US or UK, 'spider rain' is not uncommon across parts of Australia. Some species of spiders climb to the tops of plants and trees and leap off, using their web-silk as tiny parachutes to help them migrate - a process known as ballooning

displayImages.caption: 620x372 trailpic for spider Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.altText: 620x372 trailpic for spider
displayImages.cleanCaption: 620x372 trailpic for spider

cards.title: Sport picture of the day / View from the diving board

item.title: Sport picture of the day: a bird's-eye view at Red Bull Cliff Diving World Series
item.trailText: Colombia’s Orlando Duque dives high above La Rochelle in France whilst competing in the Cliff Diving World Series
item.standFirst: Colombia’s Orlando Duque dives high above 75,000 spectators in La Rochelle, France whilst competing in the Red Bull Cliff Diving World Series. Here he looks a detail of the landscape with the photographer using a very wide angle lens

displayImages.altText: Orlando Duque of Colombia dives from the 27.5 metre platform on the Saint-Nicolas Tower in La Rochelle, France
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Handout/Red Bull via Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Orlando Duque of Colombia dives from the 27.5 metre platform on the Saint Nicolas Tower above 75,000 spectators during the Red Bull Cliff Diving World Series in La Rochelle, France Photograph: Vincent Curutchet/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: Orlando Duque of Colombia dives from the 27.5 metre platform on the Saint Nicolas Tower above 75,000 spectators during the Red Bull Cliff Diving World Series in La Rochelle, France
headerImage.cleanCaption: Orlando Duque of Colombia dives from the 27.5 metre platform on the Saint Nicolas Tower above 75,000 spectators during the Red Bull Cliff Diving World Series in La Rochelle, France

item.title: Palestine's skate park
item.trailText: For Bethlehem youth, who struggle for freedom and identity in a restricted environment, skateboarding offers an outlet and connection with an international community beyond their borders
item.standFirst:
For Bethlehem youth, who struggle for freedom and identity in a restricted environment, skateboarding offers an outlet and connection with an international community beyond their borders

  • Palestine’s skate park: ramping up efforts to give kids a normal life

displayImages.caption: A dedicated group of volunteers from England, Serbia, America, Germany and Jordan, were recruited by Skate-aid to build a skatepark for vulnerable children in Bethlehem. Photograph: Samantha Robison/AptArt
displayImages.altText: SkateAid 2
displayImages.cleanCaption: A dedicated group of volunteers from England, Serbia, America, Germany and Jordan, were recruited by Skate-aid to build a skatepark for vulnerable children in Bethlehem.

displayImages.caption: To identify the park as their own, boys and girls worked with NGO AptArt and splash some colour across the concrete.  Photograph: Samantha Robison/AptArt
displayImages.altText: SkateAid 4
displayImages.cleanCaption: To identify the park as their own, boys and girls worked with NGO AptArt and splash some colour across the concrete.

displayImages.caption: A barren lot next to SOS orphanage in Bethlehem was transformed into a vibrant skatepark. Photograph: Nina Constable/AptArt
displayImages.altText: SkateAid 6
displayImages.cleanCaption: A barren lot next to SOS orphanage in Bethlehem was transformed into a vibrant skatepark.

displayImages.caption: Skating connects youth to an international community of fellow skaters.  Photograph: Samantha Robison/AptArt
displayImages.altText: SkateAid 5
displayImages.cleanCaption: Skating connects youth to an international community of fellow skaters.

displayImages.caption: British skater Harry Gerrard volunteered to teach the kids tricks. Photograph: Sebastian Hartung/AptArt
displayImages.altText: British skater Harry Gerrard
displayImages.cleanCaption: British skater Harry Gerrard volunteered to teach the kids tricks.

displayImages.caption: It is hoped that one day Jewish, Muslim and Christian children will play in the park together. But Torben Oberhellmann, the chief executive of Skate-aid, doesn’t see that happening any time soon. “It would be great to invite some youth from both sides of the wall but I don’t think that can happen now,” he says. Photograph: Samantha Robison/AptArt
displayImages.altText: Feet Bethlehem skatepark
displayImages.cleanCaption: It is hoped that one day Jewish, Muslim and Christian children will play in the park together. But Torben Oberhellmann, the chief executive of Skate-aid, doesn’t see that happening any time soon. “It would be great to invite some youth from both sides of the wall but I don’t think that can happen now,” he says.

displayImages.caption: The political climate for Palestinians is bleak but some youth find solace in the vibrancy and possibility presented by their new skate park.  Photograph: Samantha Robison/AptArt
displayImages.altText: SkateAid 7
displayImages.cleanCaption: The political climate for Palestinians is bleak but some youth find solace in the vibrancy and possibility presented by their new skate park.

cards.title: A righteous path / Mass exorcisms performed in Ethiopia

item.title: A righteous path: mass exorcisms performed in Ethiopia
item.trailText: British photographer Robert Waddingham had read that in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church priests regularly carried out Sunday morning exorcisms using holy water.
item.standFirst: British photographer Robert Waddingham journeyed to Ethiopia’s Great Rift Valley to a church near Arba Minch where Orthodox priests regularly carry out mass exorcisms using holy water. Many of those attending the ceremony come to be blessed, but there are also those seeking cures for physical ailments. Please note some images contain nudity

displayImages.caption: Crowds assemble outside the main church. The exorcism rituals are usually conducted on Sunday mornings before mass takes place for the wider congregation.
displayImages.altText: Crowds assemble outside the main church. The exorcism rituals are usually conducted on Sunday mornings before mass takes place for the wider congregation.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Crowds assemble outside the main church. The exorcism rituals are usually conducted on Sunday mornings before mass takes place for the wider congregation.

displayImages.caption: Three women inside the church: as the heat rises within the corrugated metal church, the devotion is visible on the faces of the congregation.
displayImages.altText: Three women inside the church: as the heat rises within the corrugated metal church, the devotion is visible on the faces of the congregation.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Three women inside the church: as the heat rises within the corrugated metal church, the devotion is visible on the faces of the congregation.

displayImages.caption: Before dawn, a deacon leads the way to the exorcism site of Tchana Durga Gedes Arsema, where devotees will be led en masse.
displayImages.altText: Before dawn, a deacon leads the way to the exorcism site of Tchana Durga Gedes Arsema, where devotees will be led en masse.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Before dawn, a deacon leads the way to the exorcism site of Tchana Durga Gedes Arsema, where devotees will be led en masse.

displayImages.caption: A girl is made to chant saint’s names while being struck with a cross. According to an Ethiopian myth, Eve attempted to hide her children from god, and whilst some were forgiven and remained people, others were turned into animals and the remainder were punished by being made agents of the devil. The descendents of these last group are known as ‘Buda’.
displayImages.altText: A girl is made to chant saint’s names while being struck with a cross. According to an Ethiopian myth, Eve attempted to hide her children from god, and whilst some were forgiven and remained people, others were turned into animals and the remainder were punished by being made agents of the devil. The descendents of these last group are known as ‘Buda’.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A girl is made to chant saint’s names while being struck with a cross. According to an Ethiopian myth, Eve attempted to hide her children from god, and whilst some were forgiven and remained people, others were turned into animals and the remainder were punished by being made agents of the devil. The descendents of these last group are known as ‘Buda’.

displayImages.caption: A priest holding a cross throws buckets of water over a group of men. Holy water is believed by many in the group to cure diseases including HIV and cancer.
displayImages.altText: A priest holding a cross throws buckets of water over a group of men. Holy water is believed by many in the group to cure diseases including HIV and cancer.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A priest holding a cross throws buckets of water over a group of men. Holy water is believed by many in the group to cure diseases including HIV and cancer.

displayImages.caption: A priest blesses a boy with water and a cross. The pilgrims have to be naked throughout the ceremony, but most wear a small wooden cross around their neck as a sign of faith.
displayImages.altText: A priest blesses a boy with water and a cross. The pilgrims have to be naked throughout the ceremony, but most wear a small wooden cross around their neck as a sign of faith.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A priest blesses a boy with water and a cross. The pilgrims have to be naked throughout the ceremony, but most wear a small wooden cross around their neck as a sign of faith.

displayImages.caption: Women being showered with holy water. During the ceremony men and women are generally kept apart, although all ritual activities are performed by male priests.
displayImages.altText: Women being showered with the holy water. During the ceremony men and women are generally kept apart, although all ritual activities are performed by male priests.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Women being showered with holy water. During the ceremony men and women are generally kept apart, although all ritual activities are performed by male priests.

displayImages.caption: An elderly woman is drenched with holy water. All age groups attend these ceremonies. Their popularity is increasing, partly due to increased exposure in the media and on the internet.
displayImages.altText: An elderly woman is drenched with holy water. All age groups attend these ceremonies. Their popularity is increasing, partly due to increased exposure in the media and on the internet.
displayImages.cleanCaption: An elderly woman is drenched with holy water. All age groups attend these ceremonies. Their popularity is increasing, partly due to increased exposure in the media and on the internet.

displayImages.caption: A priest blesses a boy as two men bathe under the waterfall. Many water sources, such as Tchana Durga Gedes Arsema, are considered holy, with the power to heal and exorcise unwanted spirits.
displayImages.altText: A priest blesses a boy  as two men bathe under the waterfall. Many water sources, such as Tchana Durga Gedes Arsema, are considered holy, with the power to heal and exorcise unwanted spirits.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A priest blesses a boy as two men bathe under the waterfall. Many water sources, such as Tchana Durga Gedes Arsema, are considered holy, with the power to heal and exorcise unwanted spirits.

displayImages.caption: A girl is sprayed and struck with a cross by the priest. Exorcism rituals may be linked to tribal religions that pre-date the arrival of Christianity in Ethiopia.
displayImages.altText: A girl is sprayed and struck with a cross by the priest. Exorcism rituals may be linked to tribal religions that pre-date the arrival of Christianity in Ethiopia.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A girl is sprayed and struck with a cross by the priest. Exorcism rituals may be linked to tribal religions that pre-date the arrival of Christianity in Ethiopia.

displayImages.caption: A group of women are sprayed by the priest and blessed with the cross, after being guided to the spring along the small stream bed.
displayImages.altText: A group of women are sprayed by the priest and blessed with the cross, after being guided to the spring along the small stream bed.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A group of women are sprayed by the priest and blessed with the cross, after being guided to the spring along the small stream bed.

displayImages.caption: A young pilgrim is held as he is sprayed with water and blessed with the cross before the rock wall that acts as a dam, creating a waterfall of holy water.
displayImages.altText: A young pilgrim is held as he is sprayed with water and blessed with the cross before the rock wall that acts as a dam, creating a waterfall of holy water.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A young pilgrim is held as he is sprayed with water and blessed with the cross before the rock wall that acts as a dam, creating a waterfall of holy water.

displayImages.caption: Priests involved in the ritual return to the main church for the Sunday service, where the bulk of the congregation has been worshipping.
displayImages.altText: Priests involved in the ritual return to the main church for the Sunday service, where the bulk of the congregation has been worshipping.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Priests involved in the ritual return to the main church for the Sunday service, where the bulk of the congregation has been worshipping.

displayImages.altText: Chorus members head to the stage during the final dress rehearsal of Verdi's La Traviata at the Royal Opera House
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Teri Pengilley for the Guardian

headerImage.caption: Chorus members head to the stage during the final dress rehearsal of Verdi’s La Traviata at the Royal Opera House. Today marks 150 performances of Richard Eyre’s production
